title.narrative: Community Seed Bank in Rushinga Zimbabwe

description.narrative:
The Community Seed Bank project in Southern Africa will be implemented in three countries: Zimbabwe, Zambia and Malawi by Oxfam Novib's local partner the Community Technology Development Trust (CTDT) in Zimbabwe. The project is funded by the Hans Geveling Foundation and will be implemented over the period 1 June 2018 to 31 May 2023.
Community seed banks provide space for the proper maintenance of farmers# varieties adapted to local conditions. They also serve as a basis and support for farmer field schools which train farmers how to best manage their local crop diversity. The establishment of community seed banks will strengthen farmer seed systems and improve local food and nutrition security, as well as community livelihoods. The objective of this project is therefore to strengthen farmer seed systems in the three countries by the establishment of community seed banks that will offer space for the storage of seed of farmers varieties, and provide an organizational hub for trainings in Farmer Field Schools. During the project, five (5) Community Seed Banks will be established and a total of 25 associated Farmer Field Schools (5 per seed bank) over a period of five years in the countries Zimbabwe, Zambia and Malawi.
The Community Seed Banks will store seed from (1) community-based seed production programmes, (2) collected from households, (3) collected from other areas outside the farmers# communities, and will act (4) as seed distribution and marketing points, as well as (5) farmer training venues and community information centres. The 25 Farmer Field Schools will assist communities using crop biodiversity to achieve food and nutrition security. Farmer Field Schools are empowering in that smallholder farmers are able to interact with researchers and breeders, and to contribute to the development and/or improvement of new crop varieties.

participating-org.narrative:
CCCR is a multi-stakeholder pilot initiative primarily involving local communities, NGOs, governments, universities, research organizations and policy makers. This is an applied research initiative that combines capacity development of local people to address competing claims on natural resources in their own way, by dealing with the most appropriate and sustainable ways in which farming and cropping systems can be adapted to maintain local food security under fast changing climate conditions.
CCCR explores ways to contribute to increased resilience of local people, including women, who rely on genetic diversity for food security in times of climate change. CCCR explores the possible impacts and responses to climate change together with local communities, as well as of ways to best mitigate some of the impacts and adapt to others. Objectives • To explore and analyze the impact of climate change on local agricultural production, household income, and consumption patterns and food security as case studies and pilots with relevance for wide application. • To analyze and predict the sustainability and effectiveness of current practices in on-farm management and use of plant genetic resources, under conditions of climate change. • To design on-farm management strategies that cope with and mitigate the negative effects of climate change on the conservation of plant genetic resources, on agricultural production, food consumption patterns and on food security. • To explore socio-economic and cultural changes at household and community level related to adaptationof agricultural production to climate change, including from a gender perspective. • To raise awareness of local communities on, and increase their capacity to respond to, challenges and options regarding primary and secondary changes in their livelihood conditions as influenced by climate change, addressing both male and female community members. • To contribute to capacity development of involved institutional partners in Africa and Asia, with prospects of developing into a global network. • To contribute to the reconsideration of appropriate national and international policies needed to enhance food security and to sustain local livelihoods throughthe use of local germplasm better adapted to local production conditions and the marketing of the crop products, such as seed laws,Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) laws and legislation on access and benefit-sharing (ABS).
